body:
Hi @YuriGor!

The `lodash` package itself supports cherrypicking individual modules, e.g. `lodash/pick`. 
Supporting chaining is tricky, there was an abandoned effort [here](https://github.com/lodash/babel-plugin-lodash/pull/176/files) for it, but generally if you want cherry-picked methods you'll avoid the chaining syntax.

Thank you @jdalton!
And would you recommend to rely on given lodash instance and hope it will contain all the methods I need?
Or I should cherry pick methods from lodash installed as a dependency?

In the first case, the given instance may miss some methods I need if it was optimized somehow.
Or there may be no instance at all if the client code uses babel-plugin-lodash.

In another case, if I use cherry-picked from lodash dependency methods, but client code already has these methods in the lodash instance it wants to extend - in the final bundle code will be duplicated?

Probably I need a dry module for each method, which expects prepared Lodash instance or just an object with required methods, 
and also second, a pre-imported module with cherry-picked from lodash methods already passed into dry version?

And finally there will be the main script which accepts Lodash instance, imports 'wet' modules for each extension's methods and mixins it into Lodash?

And what do you think about separate NPM modules per method? Do you think it's an inefficient technique?

You can make it a requirement for users to provide `lodash` or the subset you need. However, if you're creating a bundle then cherry-picking is the way to go. I'm not a fan of separate npm modules per method (they're a pain to keep updated).
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
